properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall continues through this afternoon. A low pressure system tracking northeastwards is bringing snow, heavy at times, across far northern Ontario. Total snowfall accumulations of 15 to 30 cm are expected. The snow will taper off from west to east this afternoon. Strong northeast winds gusting to 50 km/h at times will lead to periods of reduced visibility in blowing snow. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-11T02:32:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-10T10:33:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2590107566.2021
Area: Attawapiskat, Webequie
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts near 10 cm are forecast by Thursday morning. A frontal system moving into Alaska today will spread snow through much of the Yukon. Snow is expected to reach Old Crow this afternoon, become heaviest this evening and then taper off by early Thursday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-11T03:53:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-10T11:54:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2882433680.2021
Area: Old Crow
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall tonight. Snow continues across the region this evening. The snow is expected to be heavy at times, especially near midnight before ending Wednesday morning. Total snowfall accumulations of 10 to 15 cm are expected by Wednesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall continues tonight through Wednesday morning. A low pressure system tracking northeastwards is bringing snow, heavy at times, across Far Northern Ontario. Total snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm are expected. The snow will taper off from west to east on Wednesday morning. Strong northeast winds tonight will gust to 50 km/h at times. Heavy snow combined with strong gusts will lead to periods of reduced visibility. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-10T18:53:50-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Messy winter mix of precipitation tonight. A low pressure system tracking across Far Northern Ontario is bringing a large area of precipitation with it. Snow or a wet snow and rain mix is expected tonight. Brief periods of freezing rain are also possible. Untreated surfaces may become slippery from freezing rain and snow, resulting in difficult travel conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-10T19:10:43-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain is expected. What: Rain. Total accumulations of 15 to 25 mm are expected. Where: Parts of northeastern Ontario including Gogama, Foleyet, and Kirkland Lake. When: Wednesday morning into Thursday morning. Discussion: Rain will begin late Wednesday morning and likely last through much of the day. A break in the rain may occur Wednesday evening before an additional round overnight. Rainfall accumulations of 15 to 25 mm are anticipated. The ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall due to being frozen and snow covered. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-10T21:23:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-10T05:24:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3062839340.2021
Area: Gogama - Foleyet, Kirkland Lake - Englehart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Messy mix of wintry precipitation including a possible period of freezing rain. Precipitation is forecast to begin as showers late this morning across the area. However, by this afternoon sharply falling temperatures will allow a wintry mix of precipitation to develop. Snow and ice pellets are likely, followed by a period of freezing rain this evening and overnight. At this point in time, combined snow and ice pellet amounts of 10 cm appear possible, as well as light accretions of freezing rain. Precipitation is forecast to come to an end from west to east on Thursday. Given the expected messy mix of wintry precipitation, travel will be impacted across the area. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-11T08:13:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-10T16:14:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3410871736.2021
Area: Manitouwadge - Hornepayne, Marathon - Schreiber, Kapuskasing - Hearst - Smooth Rock Falls, Little Abitibi - Kesagami Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR PRINCE GEORGE (March 09, 2021 08:00 AM - Prince George) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Prince George because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes, respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medicalc onditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. The City of Prince Georgeâ€™s Clean Air Bylaw prohibits all open burning, including backyard burning, and land clearing burning. During air quality advisories, this bylaw also prohibits recreational fires, use of wood-burning appliances (except for sole wood burning heat users), and street sweeping activities (unless approved by an Authorized Person). Industry is required to follow permit requirements that are triggered during air quality advisories and are asked to reduce emissions wherever possible. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-11T03:53:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-10T11:54:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2233762191.2021
Area: Prince George
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. What: Heavy snow. Total accumulations of 10 to 20 cm are expected. Where: On a line approximately from Quetico Provincial Park to Pledger Lake, including Geraldton. This includes sections of Highway 11 and Highway 17. When: Tonight through Thursday morning. Discussion: Periods of heavy snow are expected tonight, with rapid snowfall accumulation and poor visibility associated. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain tonight. What: Freezing rain. Ice accretion of 3 to 7 mm is expected. Where: Primarily a corridor along and north of Highway 101, including Timmins. This includes sections of Highway 17 and Highway 11. When: Tonight into early Thursday morning. Discussion: Freezing rain is expected to develop as the temperature drops below the freezing mark tonight. Preceded with rain this afternoon, the freezing rain will likely mix with ice pellets and snow overnight into Thursday morning. Ice accretion of 3 to 7 mm is expected. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-11T08:06:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-10T16:07:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0594138385.2021
Area: White River - Dubreuilville, Wawa - Pukaskwa Park, Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls, Chapleau - Missinaibi Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Easterly winds of 50 km/h gusting to 70 will develop this afternoon near the Richardson Mountains giving reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions will improve this evening as the winds ease. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR GOLDEN (March 09, 2021 13:00 - Cranbrook) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Golden because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes, respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.

properties.Summary:
Description: 2 to 5 millimetres of freezing precipitation are expected beginning tonight through Thursday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous.
